claims: Starting from the premise that biology has been informationalized, we argue that biological exchange is not only a threat to humans and the institutional structures they create, it is also, importantly, a political and economic opportunity for firms and core states involved in global health security, and one of the key bases for an emergent global political economy of health security

Akin to Naomi Klein’s argument on disaster capitalism, in which profit is to be made and power is to be gained from the misfortunes of others, we argue that global bioinsecurities present a political economic opportunity, especially for Western states and institutions, to protect and grow their bio-economies and thus to bolster both their geopolitical power and national economic interests (Klein, 2007)
To capture the political economy that is sedimenting around networked forms of informationalized biology, we introduce the idea of a somatic-security industrial complex (SSIC)

To take this forward we provide a brief review of the global health security literature showing how the global health security agenda (GHSA) largely focuses on the idea that infectious disease is an existential threat to western nations and how this perception engenders a narrow, western and statist response bent on defending against the dangers of biological exchange

Rather than focus on bodies swept up in the unpredictable ‘biological cauldron’ of the twenty-first century, we focus on the ways that they are promoted, modulated, and managed in the name of global health security (Braun, 2007)

Taking a different tack than the literature in global health security outlined above, we argue that efforts to mitigate the vulnerability of human populations, and the vital systems that support them, have engendered a political economy of global health that not only fosters global biological exchange, but requires it

If, as Nikolas Rose has argued, in the vital politics of the twenty-first century, the existence of humans becomes a focus of government; the target of novel forms of authority and expertise; a highly cathected field for knowledge; an expanding territory for bioeconomic exploitation; an organizing principle for ethics and the stake in a molecular politics; then, we argue that these vital politics are increasingly exercised in and through an understanding of life as information (Rose, 2007)
In order to shed light on this other side of biological exchange, we have shown how understandings of biological life, capitalism and security have all been reconfigured, both together and separately

It is for this reason that we argue that, to the extent that the political economy of global health security relies on an informationalized form of life and insofar as western nations are leading the GHSA, the proliferation and promotion rather than the prevention and mitigation of biological exchange is central to the political economy of global health security today

To capture the political economy that is sedimenting around networked forms of informationalized biology, we introduce the idea of a somatic-security industrial complex (SSIC)

We ground our discussion in the biological exchanges taking place in the research and circulation of influenza virus, the only known pathogen to cause a pandemic, and a core concern of global health security (WHO Fact Sheet). To take this forward we provide a brief review of the global health security literature showing how the global health security agenda (GHSA) largely focuses on the idea that infectious disease is an existential threat to western nations and how this perception engenders a narrow, western and statist response bent on defending against the dangers of biological exchange

Taking a different tack than the literature in global health security outlined above, we argue that efforts to mitigate the vulnerability of human populations, and the vital systems that support them, have engendered a political economy of global health that not only fosters global biological exchange, but requires it

Mirroring the self-generating technologies it is promoting, ‘the life sciences have played a commanding role in America’s strategies of economic and imperialist self-reinvention’ (Cooper, 2008, p. 4). When this circulation is forestalled or prevented, as in the case of Indonesia failing to share its flu virus or when China both harbors the genetic information of its population and seeks to purchase that of other countries including the United States, both the geopolitical dominance and economic well-being of those most invested in global health security are at stake. It is for this reason that we argue that, to the extent that the political economy of global health security relies on an informationalized form of life and insofar as western nations are leading the global health security agenda, the proliferation and promotion rather than the prevention and mitigation of biological exchange is central to the political economy of global health security today

The political economy we outline here has already been signalled through the theorization of novel state-market relations built around molecules; in new forms of capital built around biology and pharmaceuticals (Sunder Rajan, 2006); new forms of global health financing (Sands & Chawla, 2017); and in wider research on the emerging bioeconomy (Cooper, 2008; Dietz, Bo€rner, Fo€rster, & von Braun, 2018)

These works do not explicitly address the way that the informationalization of life itself plays a central role in all of these phenomena and in contributing to the emergence of what we refer to as the somatic security industrial complex. This complex relies on the latent labor of informationalized life and seeks to harness itsproductive potential through biological exchange
